												Disclaimer:I suggest to start with Matthewmatosis's review where all of the problems of DS2 are summarized:


YouTube™ Video: Dark Souls 2 Critique 

			Views: 840,426		

			After finding myself let down by Dark Souls 2 I wanted to talk about many of the problems I had with it. This is a critique, not a full review.		

____My playtime for DS1 was about 110h.I gave DS2 a several tries and finally completed brining a total playtime to 67h.I guess in the end there are two major fractions of the Souls fanbase:* The fans of the game (this group complains about stuff like lore and immersion)* The fans of the metagame (this group very notably demand you to have at least 200 hours in the game to be able to voice any kind of opinion).For the second group DS2 is on pair or maybe even better than the DS1 with better fps, better pvp, larger variety of weapons and overall better mechanic. I think they don't really care about the game itself as the artistic product, but merely as a medium for their metagaming experience. Convenience is all about metagame and DS2 is definitely more convenient.For the first group DS is all about the game experience and the immersion. And from this point of view DS2 is absolutely abysmal. Every single design decision of the DS2 is simply not working in favor of game. What's worse, every bad design decision triggers a cascade of other problems and they snowball.* Levels are poorly connected, and often make no sense thematically.* NPC are completely uninteresting and too verbose.* The lore and story are virtually non existing.* Bosses are repetitive, often use the same movesets and are mostly recycled versions of other enemies.* Soul memory is not really working in favor of local coop.* Closely placed bonfires break immersion.* You have to go back to hub to level up which breaks immersion even more.* If you are using rings of protection you are completely deprived of any sense of challenge.* If you are not using ring of protection, you are faced with extremely limited human effigies and inability to farm them (as monsters are limited in this game).I can go on and on about it, but I guess you can get my point.

												Yes, there is a version of this game with DirectX 11 coming out, and yes it's supposed to be superior to this version. edit: it also includes all the DLC.Should that stop you from buying this version? Definitely NOT.Dark Souls 2 is a refreshing change of pace from most games that are typically being released (with the exception of a few games, ex. Wasteland 2, I also recommend that game!) with the idea of a combat heavy RPG. What makes this game different than the rest? I would personally have to say it's the detail and variety that goes into everything, like the lore, there are so many hints about some whatever scattered around in item descriptions, dialouge, and even the area you are in. There is also a ton of variety and originallity to be had with the surplus or weapons, armor, and rings the game will supply you with to keep you playing. In fact, there is so much variety that "Fashion Souls" is an actual thing, and AWESOME.  Everyone should know by now that this is supposed to be a hard game, and it is. It can be very tough on a beginner especially, but do NOT fret because it may be hard, but it's not unfair. The game will give you the advantage of being able to observe your enemy, learn their moveset, or they will give you an opening to go through to make things easier, give you a shortcut every now and then. Something like that. So the point is to not let the difficulty stop you from playing this game, because it can be overcome with some simple strategy.  The PvP is flawed, but not bad. You will run into jerks with a rapier that shoots magic and then spam you with it, yes there will be people wearing the Jester's top to prevent backstabs then spam attacks, but you will also meet a lot of people who use original builds or builds that will inspire you to maybe change up your build. Overall I would have to recommend this game to anybody who is looking for a fun game with an active community, or just anyone that wants to be challenged. I know there will be people who say this game is awful for the reasons of PvP or PvE, in fact I met someone who quit this game because L3 was jump. Do not be like that guy, because he used petty reasons to not try something DIFFERENT.

												Ruined expectations: The game. Where do I begin? The PvE is okay but nowhere near as good as in DaS1 or DeS: bosses are forgettable, most NPCs are there only for the purpose of buying items and nothing more, the OST is lacking, the ending was terrible and so was the final boss.The PvP is outright broken, "great" mechanics such as Soul Memory allow SL838s and SL150s to fight each other just because they have gained enough souls to be in the same SM range. It ends up with everyone using the same build since holding back on leveling up will leave yourself in disadvantage. Full Havel's/Santier's/Avelyns/hexes/monastery. Where's the fun in fighting that and just that? Not to mention that full Havel's makes your damage a joke. The PvP in the Souls series was always all about creating new imaginative builds and learning how to handle them with skill. In DaS1 or DeS your armor didn't really matter as much as it does here. An SL1 could beat an SL500 with a certain amount of skill. Not here, because the new engine makes controlling your character nowhere as good.I finished DS1 in 80 hours and the rest were put in PvP because there was always fun in making and fighting different builds. I don't have the motivation to continue playing this game. It's not possible to have fun while soul memory is a thing. I have many doubts that it will go away but we can only hope that it does.Only worth purchasing on a sale for PvE. In its current state it's not worth buying if you're willing to buy it for the PvP that comes afterwards.

												Yes, very recommended but...only for those who played Demon's Souls or Dark Souls and want some more without high expectations about the story.In general terms I really loved Dark Souls II. First Souls game with native HD and beyond resolutions for PC. Also the 60 FPS was a very important "must". The plot and lore are not that great as Dark Souls PTDE but it has his own good moments. This new entry is full of new items and some other little interesting mechanics like the coffin of Things Betwixt, the life gems and some new covenants. It was fun to discover them through the game. The humanity thing remains but this time is easier to handle. In general Dark Souls II has a lot of things to make the difficulty of newcomers easier (wich I recommend you don't abuse if you played a Souls before).About Souls and leveling this time you do it between Emerald Gerald in Majula. Similar to the Maiden in Black from Demon's Souls Nexus.About visual and sound...mmm... Visually is not mind blowing but is an step forward from PC Dark Souls with DS Fix. The art looks fantastic in lighting terms. Maybe is different in it's style in terms of environments and enemies design. A lot more cliche but enjoyable. Oh! rag doll is off in this game...and the lighting and assets from it's first gameplay shown to the world ¬¬ The sound design (foley etc) is good. But the music score is something I recommend you didn't expect to be better than previous games. But is good!...Take listen to Demon's Souls for instance. It has some interesting flutes and leitmotifs wich are missing on the next game. I find the Intro, Phalanx or the adjudicator one the most memorable ones. In Dark Souls there's a great variety of styles and there's even more memorable songs. And unfortunate for those who love the music of this games Dark Souls II is kind of flat...epic but flat. That doesn't mean i doesn't have it's moments ;)About the important thing...Gameplay. It's almost the same but more responsive and smooth. The kick was replaced for the shoulder push. But there's a lot more weapon styles even bare hands styles. I find my self on PvP with players with very strange setups xD and of course two hackers in a few months (I'm not very expect on the PvP thing). The only downside here is that "Soul Memory System" wich is not optional. The co-op. Now you can summon two players the NPC of the area you're (if it's available) and an internet player. This can make the game much easier. I don't recommend this much. I find myself solving some bosses with this method and then feeling horrible haha. But never again!Mmmm Boss Fights...they're not that interesting as the areas they're on. But there are some of this friends wich you'll hate at the same level as before.I think Dark Souls II is not a bad entry at all (BTW Hidetaka Miyazaki just supervised it but it wasn't it's director). We can't say is a bad game. Maybe a transition. I think it's better than have a hole until Bloodborne is released and of course it deserves it's price ;)

												So I've just acquired 100% of the achievements to the game, and although it was totally unnecessary, I feel I'm qualified to write a review now.First of all; I started the game and I finished the game with keyboard and mouse. The default keybindings I found pretty terrible to be honest, and the game using Xbox controller key prompts made it all the more frustrating. After having played with a controller and changing the keys to my liking though, I have to say that I couldn't bring myself to go back to the controller.Dark Souls II has fairly decent graphics, but falls short of triple A releases. It makes up for that with a smooth 60 frames per second which is absolutely vital in a game like this which requires you to patiently learn enemies moves while dodging death by the breadth of a hair. Fortunately you don't need a beast of a PC to run it either, with my average (or below) set up of an AMD Radeon HD 6780 + four gigs of RAM I experienced maybe three or four frame drops through my ten characters.The game itself is really quite challenging. Casual gamers I'd imagine would have a hell of a time trying to adapt and I'd highly reccommend searching for the hidden attributes in some stats and what they fully affect, while Hardcore gamers will have plenty of room to trip up as well. Don't fret if the game feels too intimidating, failing is a large part of every Souls players first experience, it's the ecstacy in beating the jerk after your tenth try for some sweet revenge and coming back later in the game when you're more experienced to take the time to torture them.As far as Online Play goes... You'll find a lot of fantastic people willing to engage in jolly cooperation, but keep in mind that there are no rules in the Dark Souls universe, in a broken and decaying Kingdom it's every man for themselves and some people just want to watch the world burn.

												This game will hand you a flimsy bit of wood, a broken bit of metal, then point you at a dude the size of a house, with a mace bigger than your whole body, and tell you to go kill him. You will die. A lot. And you will LOVE it! This game is brutal, infuriating at times, but incredibly satisfying when you finally kick the ♥♥♥ of that one boss that was throwing your ragdoll all over the boss cavern. There's nothing quite like it anymore either. Games have become far too easy. Far too "casual" to use the vernacular. This game is the counter to that. It starts hard and you can increase the difficult as much as you like either by starting New Game Plus (NG+) over and over, getting harder each time, or you can use items at the game's bonfire's that will increase the difficulty in that specific area permenantly. There are advantages to doing this, however, and many items / spells etc will only drop / become available on harder NG+. The community is also one of the more helpful that i've found. It being a mainly single player experience, but with the opportunity to do some "jolly co-op" by summoning allies to help fight difficult areas or tough bosses you feel you want a hand with. You can also go help others in order to gain various benefits. There is also the option to be a dickbag and invade other players with the sole purpose of killing them and stealing their humanity. Either way it's all tied together with the fantastic combat system.The gameplay is brutal but fair. Even fairly "basic" enemies can still kill you far into the game if you mess up your block or dodge or parry. But equally you can read their patterns and learn how to deal with them without taking any hits once you're practiced. There is so much to explore, so many side quests to uncover, secrets to puzzle out, hidden walls and illusions to find. You can play as a high strength / dex blademaster build then change your mind and respec to a full on fire throwing lightning slinging magic user when you feel like it using a (somewhat) rare consumable. On the topic of magic.... spells in Dark Souls are JUST as punishing as weapons. If not MORE so. There are some insanely powerful spells in the game and the limited uses per spell before you need to rest at a bonfire allows for them to be balanced. The sheer insane variety of ways to play and different builds available makes it a game i'm STILL not bored of, and STILL discovering more and more about. I've not even started the DLC's yet and i'm over 150 hours in on my main character. Sadly bows are somewhat lacklustre in the Souls universe which i attribute to balance reasons. They tend to require a lot of stamina to shoot compared to similar weight melee weapons, and their damage is pretty limited for the most part. There are some greatbows that launch treetrunks at people and can do heavy damage, but are so slow to fire and in pvp will leave you an easy target. I've always loved archery and all things bow related in my games, but even with the limited power of bows in Dark Souls II i'm happy with my Hunter's Blackbow +10's damage output. It's the fastest firing bow and takes less stamina than most. I combo it with poison arrows and can poison 90% of enemies in 1 volley (how many arrows i can fire before out of stamina) which is extremely useful in certain areas. Even with my love of bows, and normal preference for ranged classes, i don't find myself caring in DSII. The melee weapons are so varied and satisfying to use that i'm perfectly satisfied to use a mix of ranged bow shots to pick off tougher enemies / thin the pack, before taking out the rest with my swordplay.The whole game just feels so incredibly satisfying when you get good, and even when you "think" you're good, there's always the other player invaders to show you how wrong you are :P

29, 2014
												Playing Dark Souls II reminds me of old video games like Into The Eagles Nest and Ghosts and Goblins where the technology was so limited that enemies were ultimately fair, tutorials were non-existent, and I didn't mind playing the same level over and over memorizing and perfecting it.  Dark Souls isnt exactly fun all the time, but it is engaging and satisfying.  Its more like a challenge, keep that in mind as you calibrate your expectations and you can get over the initial steep learning curve.  I died at least 4 times before the tutorial section even started.  But the tutorial was actually effective if you pay attention and attempt to apply it as the game continues.  The story is very light and absorbed through infrequent NPC character dialogue so it is importatnt that you aren't expecting a strong story or character driven narrative.  The difficulty ramp has been even over time, with the exception of bosses which are very short and brutal until you get the hang of that particular boss.  As you progress, the enemies become more varied so to encourage varied tactics from encounter to encounter.  This is not a game with which you can check-out and just enjoy.  You have to focus on the enemies actions and responding appropriately.  There are no exclamation points to warn you of an incoming attack.  The game requires that you use all of the available mechanics, first order optimizations will only lead to frequent deaths and frustration.  The enemies have access to all of the same abilities as you, the player.  In this way, it is scrupulously fair.  Ambushes are always detectable if you are paying attention.  No monster closets or enemies popping into existence because you crossed a threshold. It is a game to focus on and feel satisfied when you succeed.  So far, I am really enjoying it.  Note: I didn't play Dark Souls or Demon Souls.  I havent engaged in any multiplayer, though it exists in a coop form where friends can help you with boss fights and a PVP form where presumably frustrating people do frustrating things.

												The way ahead is completely covered in darkness. Apart from a few points of light in the distance and the orange glow that comes from the bonfire behind you, you can't see anything. You decide to light your torch, which casts its light over a small area around you. You don`t have much oil left to keep it burning, but it will have to do. Cautiously, you start moving.After scouting the location a little, you realize you are at the top of a big rock overlooking a dock. In the far distance, an immense ghost ship lies floating in the water. Somehow you feel that's where you are supposed to go.The path from the rock to the docks leads you through an abandoned village, now inhabited only by the undead. Creeping from every corner, they lunge at you from the darkness. Street after street and house after house you make battle with them, getting each time closer to the docks. The voyage takes more time than you previously expected though, and soon your weapon begins to degrade from beating against the metal your enemies were wearing at the time of their deaths.Soon, you find yourself with just an almost broken sword, no more healing items and a torch whose light is about to fade away. You are, however, much closer to the ship. You can see it more clearly now, its ragged sails wavering in the wind, calling you. Taking a deep breath, you go for the final stretch of the journey, hoping your now depleted inventory will be able to get you there in one piece.You find the bell that calls the ship to port just as the light of your torch finally dies. This is it, you`ve made it. Now all you must do is board the ship and hopefully a bonfire will be waiting for you at the deck. What you find inside though, is disappointing: more enemies. They are dispatched quickly but that doesn't do any good to your already worn off sword.You find the stairs leading to the ship`s quarters. That has to be it. By the end of these steps you hope only to find the long awaited bonfire, a place where you can rest, recover your healing items and fix your gear. Step after step you descend anxiously, turning the camera at the end to explore the room at which you arrive.The room is empty, except for a table, some chairs and... a fog door, which indicates a boss fight is imminent.  That's all you didn't need right now. Without any means to recover your health and carrying only a dull blade, the terrifying prospect of having to walk through that entire dark place all over again starts to creep up on you. Without any other choice, you buckle up and cross the damned gate.The vision that greets you is terrifying. A pair of giant skeletons, bound to each other like siamese twins, each armed with a pair of blades are already walking towards you, their feet chirping in the water that covers the floor of the flooded room. Without any items to recover your health, you know you can't afford to take even a single hit. So you raise your shield and keep your distance, studying the movements of the beast. After avoiding a few of its attacks you start feeling confident and are able to deliver them a few hits when their guard is down.The fight progresses slowly, as you only attack when you are sure it's safe to. The boss' movements are easy to predict and it starts to feel that victory will be yours, so long as you keep your strategy going.The skeletons' health drops to its half. Again they move to deliver the same pattern of attacks they've been doing since the beginning of the fight. You know how to react: just roll to the right, wait for them to raise their blades again, roll again to the right... and unexpectedly get hit in the face by a blow that totally shouldn't have gotten you. What happened? You were able to dodge all of their attacks so far, but this last one hit you despite you having done exactly the same movements as before.As you try to gain some distance from the creature, you notice you are moving slower. Why is this happening? The fight that was almost a sure victory has become a real nightmare. As the monster lifts his blades in the air for yet another blow, you realize in terror what has been going on: the water level in the room has been steadily rising since you entered the area.Welcome to Dark Souls.

content:
, 2014
												So i've recently been asked to write a full review of this game while completely ignoring that its a part of the souls series. As such i'm going to do just that.While the game is not a bad game it is flawed in many ways. Allow me to explain why.1 - Being hardNow, i say that its hard, but I'm not complaining about it being hard in the traditional sense. I'm not asking for an easier game either since in my opinion that'd be 20 kinds of dumb.I'm complaining about this because, while i enjoy a good challenging game, this game is hard just for the sake of being hard.Allow me to exemplify. There is an optional area in the game where the boss consists of 4 minions and the boss itself. The boss is untargetable until you attack one of the 4 minions, meaning you can't weaken him before commencing the fight. As for the minions, the second you attack one of them the remaining 3 immediately become agressive and attack you giving you around 5 seconds or so to dispatch them before the boss drops into the area and begins attacking you as well. This would be fine if the minions didn't inflict a status effect that deals a large ammount of damage over time with a mere 2 hits. This means you have to deal with the 4 minions, as quickly as possible, without getting hit twice and possibly have to deal with the boss itself should you fail to dispatch the critters in time.This is not what i'd call challenging, but as a gigantic pain the the neck instead. This isn't the only fight where this happens, but i'd rather not delve too much into it.2 - CombatWhile combat itself is pretty okay, i have some problems with it. Call it nitpicking if you will but there are just some things that don't really feel right.The hitboxes feel off sometimes, there's no other way to describe it, while playing i'll sometimes  see the effect caused by a weapon clearly hitting my opponent without it actually happening, and it makes me wonder if something is actually wrong with either my game or my computer.Another interesting little thing is that enemies never grow tired. The game itself has a stamina mechanic that forces you to think before you act, but enemies can dish out a flurry of attacks even though (from the story's/game perspective), they're in the same pseudo-zombified state as the player, the same can be said for their attack tracking ability, by this i mean there are certain enemies that will literally turn 180 degrees while in the middle of an attack just so they can attempt to hit you (in fact this was so bad in one specific enemy, that the developers actually had to reduce the tracking capabilities on said enemy's projectiles).This feels a bit off, and dare I say, makes the game harder, just for the sake of being harder.3 - Covenants.This'll be a short one. You have no idea what you're getting yourself into. That's it. when you interact with someone or something that allows you to join a covenant, you get no information about what you're getting yourself into. In fact this occurred to a good friend of mine. While he was playing he found an object that allowed him to join a covenant, simply asking him if he's ready to face a bigger challenge. He then found out that by entering this covenant his damage was reduced and that he was unable to summon any NPCs or players into his world for help.I may be mistaken, but there are several several possible outcomes when one decides do say that something will result in a bigger challenge. Usually people who decide to face a bigger challenge know what sort of mess they're getting themselves into.This isn't the case.4 - NPCsInteraction with NPCs isn't really anything to write home about in most games, but some things in Dark Souls 2 annoy me. Allow me to exemplify. In this game you are only allowed to level up by speaking with one specific NPC. Now instead of opening the menu and letting said NPC talk while you're navigating through the menu you are forced to skip 4 dialogue segments before you are finally allowed to level up.Now, in this game you'll be interacting with this NPC quite a few times, seeing as this is the NPC that allows you to increase the number of innate healing items you possess in your inventory along with allowing you to level up. The result is that these "interactions" become extremely annoying extremely early in the game. Truth be told this is not something that should happen when you're dealing with an "important" NPC, or any other NPC for that matter.5 - PvPLast but not least, we have PvP. An addition to the game that should be fun filled, challenging and overall allow the player to enjoy him/herself even more.If it was actually balanced that is.Now in PvP (or Invasions) your goal is to either defeat the invader or the invaded (depending on whether you're invading or being invaded), but lets talk about accessing PvP first. there are 3 main PvP covenants within the game. One of them grants you a ring that automatically summons you into one of two areas in the game where you must face off against the player that set foot within that area. As a reward for this you get titanite chunks, which are relatively hard to come by and allow you to reinforce your weapons and armor.The remaining two covenants make mostly use of cracked eye orbs (although one of these covenants gives you a ring that allows you to aid players from another covenant while said players are being invaded). The thing is, in your first playthrough, you are only given access to a limited number of orbs, making invasions during your first (and possibly even last) playthrough limited as well. Please note that these covenants require an immense ammount of invasions for the player to rank up (requiring a total of 500 victories for the player to achieve the third and final rank).As for a way of replenishing eye orbs the player is given two options. Duel against players from the same covenant or buy them for a ridiculous ammount of souls in New Game +. Dueling on its own is a pain because you have to consume a different token for each covenant (these are obtained by either using eye orbs and defeating an invaded player, or by aiding another player as a phantom). As a result, invasions during a player's first playthrough are extremely rare should you decide not to venture into the area protected by the 1st mentioned PvP covenant.That aside there is also the case of extreme unbalance. The game features spells that can easily instantly kill a player for a measly soul cost or buff already hard hitting weapons along with weapons with a ridiculous attack speed or maybe even phantom reach (meaning that their reach is longer than it actually appears to be).My main issue with this is that some of the builds that focus on using these spells/weapons, are relatively easy to make, and as a result my PvP experience went downhill at an astonishing speed.Weaponry aside, invaders are unable to recover HP without resorting to spells. Making it so that even if the invading is actually fighting well, and in a fair way, nothing is stopping the invaded player from running away/hiding so that he/she may recover HP and then rush back into the fight without almost any form of punishment whatsoever. This just helps make PvP even more unbalanced (not to mention the fact that a player may summon 2 other players to their aid, turning the fight into a 3 vs 1 where the opposing trio has the ability to regenerate health).6 - ConclusionPlease note that these are my opinions and that people are free to disagree with me, its also likely that its just me who's just bad at the game in which case i've been trying to git gud for a very long time, but the game as a whole has several blatant design flaws once you take a very good look at it, and while it is good on its own, it could have been a much better game in the end. So while i do recommend this game, i'd wait for a discount.

												Don't get me wrong by this recommendation. I love Dark Souls 2 (and I think I'm one of the few that like it better than Dark Souls 1). But......If you are new to the Souls series, or don't yet own Dark Souls 2 for the PC, don't buy this game. Wait until Scholar of the First Sin comes out in 2015 (currently slated to be released in April). It is purported to be a vastly improved experience, with new enemies, NPCs, and quests - along with improved graphics. It will run in DX11, so make sure your computer will be able to handle it.I DON'T like the fact that they will make the people who already own Dark Souls 2 re-purchase a game that is essentially an updated/patched version. It would be one thing if it were a DLC patch. But buying the entire game again and (most likely) losing all game progress? Not to mention the two games will be on differnt servers and thus unable to play with one another, thus splitting the already-limited community. What the hell, From Software? That's an incredibly unethical business practice if I've ever seen one. It makes EA, Ubisoft, and Activision look ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed consumer-concious by comparison.Sigh. Not sure if I'm actually going to buy the new game or not. I want the better version, but I don't want to support a blatant cash-grab that is clearly just aiming to milk our wallets. Purchase it, or don't. It's entirely up to you. I probably won't.

content:
, 2014
												So i've recently been asked to write a full review of this game while completely ignoring that its a part of the souls series. As such i'm going to do just that.While the game is not a bad game it is flawed in many ways. Allow me to explain why.1 - Being hardNow, i say that its hard, but I'm not complaining about it being hard in the traditional sense. I'm not asking for an easier game either since in my opinion that'd be 20 kinds of dumb.I'm complaining about this because, while i enjoy a good challenging game, this game is hard just for the sake of being hard.Allow me to exemplify. There is an optional area in the game where the boss consists of 4 minions and the boss itself. The boss is untargetable until you attack one of the 4 minions, meaning you can't weaken him before commencing the fight. As for the minions, the second you attack one of them the remaining 3 immediately become agressive and attack you giving you around 5 seconds or so to dispatch them before the boss drops into the area and begins attacking you as well. This would be fine if the minions didn't inflict a status effect that deals a large ammount of damage over time with a mere 2 hits. This means you have to deal with the 4 minions, as quickly as possible, without getting hit twice and possibly have to deal with the boss itself should you fail to dispatch the critters in time.This is not what i'd call challenging, but as a gigantic pain the the neck instead. This isn't the only fight where this happens, but i'd rather not delve too much into it.2 - CombatWhile combat itself is pretty okay, i have some problems with it. Call it nitpicking if you will but there are just some things that don't really feel right.The hitboxes feel off sometimes, there's no other way to describe it, while playing i'll sometimes  see the effect caused by a weapon clearly hitting my opponent without it actually happening, and it makes me wonder if something is actually wrong with either my game or my computer.Another interesting little thing is that enemies never grow tired. The game itself has a stamina mechanic that forces you to think before you act, but enemies can dish out a flurry of attacks even though (from the story's/game perspective), they're in the same pseudo-zombified state as the player, the same can be said for their attack tracking ability, by this i mean there are certain enemies that will literally turn 180 degrees while in the middle of an attack just so they can attempt to hit you (in fact this was so bad in one specific enemy, that the developers actually had to reduce the tracking capabilities on said enemy's projectiles).This feels a bit off, and dare I say, makes the game harder, just for the sake of being harder.3 - Covenants.This'll be a short one. You have no idea what you're getting yourself into. That's it. when you interact with someone or something that allows you to join a covenant, you get no information about what you're getting yourself into. In fact this occurred to a good friend of mine. While he was playing he found an object that allowed him to join a covenant, simply asking him if he's ready to face a bigger challenge. He then found out that by entering this covenant his damage was reduced and that he was unable to summon any NPCs or players into his world for help.I may be mistaken, but there are several several possible outcomes when one decides do say that something will result in a bigger challenge. Usually people who decide to face a bigger challenge know what sort of mess they're getting themselves into.This isn't the case.4 - NPCsInteraction with NPCs isn't really anything to write home about in most games, but some things in Dark Souls 2 annoy me. Allow me to exemplify. In this game you are only allowed to level up by speaking with one specific NPC. Now instead of opening the menu and letting said NPC talk while you're navigating through the menu you are forced to skip 4 dialogue segments before you are finally allowed to level up.Now, in this game you'll be interacting with this NPC quite a few times, seeing as this is the NPC that allows you to increase the number of innate healing items you possess in your inventory along with allowing you to level up. The result is that these "interactions" become extremely annoying extremely early in the game. Truth be told this is not something that should happen when you're dealing with an "important" NPC, or any other NPC for that matter.5 - PvPLast but not least, we have PvP. An addition to the game that should be fun filled, challenging and overall allow the player to enjoy him/herself even more.If it was actually balanced that is.Now in PvP (or Invasions) your goal is to either defeat the invader or the invaded (depending on whether you're invading or being invaded), but lets talk about accessing PvP first. there are 3 main PvP covenants within the game. One of them grants you a ring that automatically summons you into one of two areas in the game where you must face off against the player that set foot within that area. As a reward for this you get titanite chunks, which are relatively hard to come by and allow you to reinforce your weapons and armor.The remaining two covenants make mostly use of cracked eye orbs (although one of these covenants gives you a ring that allows you to aid players from another covenant while said players are being invaded). The thing is, in your first playthrough, you are only given access to a limited number of orbs, making invasions during your first (and possibly even last) playthrough limited as well. Please note that these covenants require an immense ammount of invasions for the player to rank up (requiring a total of 500 victories for the player to achieve the third and final rank).As for a way of replenishing eye orbs the player is given two options. Duel against players from the same covenant or buy them for a ridiculous ammount of souls in New Game +. Dueling on its own is a pain because you have to consume a different token for each covenant (these are obtained by either using eye orbs and defeating an invaded player, or by aiding another player as a phantom). As a result, invasions during a player's first playthrough are extremely rare should you decide not to venture into the area protected by the 1st mentioned PvP covenant.That aside there is also the case of extreme unbalance. The game features spells that can easily instantly kill a player for a measly soul cost or buff already hard hitting weapons along with weapons with a ridiculous attack speed or maybe even phantom reach (meaning that their reach is longer than it actually appears to be).My main issue with this is that some of the builds that focus on using these spells/weapons, are relatively easy to make, and as a result my PvP experience went downhill at an astonishing speed.Weaponry aside, invaders are unable to recover HP without resorting to spells. Making it so that even if the invading is actually fighting well, and in a fair way, nothing is stopping the invaded player from running away/hiding so that he/she may recover HP and then rush back into the fight without almost any form of punishment whatsoever. This just helps make PvP even more unbalanced (not to mention the fact that a player may summon 2 other players to their aid, turning the fight into a 3 vs 1 where the opposing trio has the ability to regenerate health).6 - ConclusionPlease note that these are my opinions and that people are free to disagree with me, its also likely that its just me who's just bad at the game in which case i've been trying to git gud for a very long time, but the game as a whole has several blatant design flaws once you take a very good look at it, and while it is good on its own, it could have been a much better game in the end. So while i do recommend this game, i'd wait for a discount.

												Is it as good as the first game? Actually, yes. The mechanics in this game are refined and flushed out in lacking areas, while fat was trimmed from flawed areas (like weapon upgrading) in the prior titles. This game has issues, just like Dark souls 1 had, but they are different issues, and while they bother some individuals (like myself) more than the issues of the first Dark souls game, others may find this game a refreshing step forward for the franchise. A worthy purchase, especially if you can catch it on sale. If you are looking for a populated multiplayer experience as your main draw, however, I will point you kindly to the playstation version, as that community will assuredly remain the most active in PvP

ber 3, 2014
												I haven’t played Dark Souls 1 or its predecessor Demon Souls so I can’t speak to how similar Dark Souls II (DS2) is to either of them. I can say however that if the previous games are as hard as DS2, I probably don’t want to play those either. I only played this game for a few hours so keep that in mind when weighing my opinion.In DS2 you start the game as some sort of undead being. You are warned about the dangers of becoming “Hollow” which I guess is a kind of damned spirit. The game’s narration has the feel of a dream where you’re not entirely sure what’s going on but you have an idea of what you’re supposed to do. The game follows your progress towards reaching “The King” (and probably fighting him). Obviously I didn’t get far enough to see how that works out. There are a number of neutral people that you meet on your quest that you can talk to or interact with, but large portions of the game world seem uninhabited. By the way, some of the people can be hard to see since they blend into the environment very well (people kind of sit around in random places). I’m used to games where objects and people have some sort of highlight around them to improve visibility.I was a little disappointed in the game’s graphics to be honest. I thought that being a modern game DS2 would have slick high definition gameplay, but actually the textures are similar to older games such as Darksiders 2. I’m not saying it’s bad (it’s still pretty good), just that I expected a 2014 AAA title to be amazing. One bright side to this is that my 3 year old computer didn’t have any problems running the game. The game is clearly a console port so playing on a game controller is strongly recommended. Since I have very little experience using controllers (I don’t own any consoles) I first tried Keyboard + Mouse. This didn’t work out so well since performing even basic actions would require combinations of keys. For example, the “action” button would be shift+left click. And when using keyboard + mouse, the on-screen prompts would be for controller keys (Press A button to pick up item). After a few hours play I still haven’t figured out how to put items on the “quick use” belt.When people describe the Dark Souls games probably the first thing mentioned is usually the difficulty. The game is very hard because you have no “advantage” over any of your enemies. It takes them only a few hits to kill you just as it takes you a few hits to kill them. You also have a stamina bar which limits how often you can swing your weapon. This means you can’t just dive into a battle chopping with your sword and hope that you make the first strike. There are no “weak” enemies; everyone can all kill you in seconds if you’re not paying attention. And if you die, you lose ALL your money/experience and respawn with lower max health. The money/experience of the game is counted in “souls” which are used as both currency and experience for leveling up. You have an opportunity to retrieve the souls you drop on death, but if you die again before picking them up (happens a lot because enemies respawn), they’re lost permanently. I can only imagine what some of the later boss battles must be like. Pros:+The game can be immersive and is actually fair. Every time you die you’ll kick yourself because you know that if you had done it “right” you wouldn’t have died.+I like how the money and experience is combined into “souls” which are automatically gained on killing an enemy. I get easily tired of looting corpses in RPGs.+The game is challenging and I’m sure you’d feel like a god if you actually beat it.Cons:-Dark Souls 2 is too hard for me. If you didn’t have your life bar shrunk with every death I wouldn’t mind doing some grinding, but as it is the game just gets harder and harder as you die.-The controls (even with a controller) can be hard to master if you’re not experienced with this kind of game. The platform jumping was especially annoying for me since it takes a combination of buttons to accomplish a simple jump. And if you fall, you die.-The level up system is not very well explained. You start at around level 12 depending on what class you chose and you’re not told very clearly how many souls you need per level up. On level up you get to increase 1 stat, and it’s not clearly explained what each stat does. I’m sure I could read up on it online before playing the game, but I don’t like having to research a game before playing.-The game has no “objective clues” or game map. You’re just given this large game world to explore at random.Overall I’m not going to recommend the game unless you’ve played the previous ones. All of the cons I mentioned would probably melt away after you’ve played through the game at least once. I thought the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. games were weak too but I enjoyed them after playing through at least one time. Then you’d know where to go and what you need to do (including what order you should explore areas in). If you’ve never played the previous Dark Souls games and don’t like super challenging games, stay away from Dark Souls II until the price drops. The game has a meta rating over 90% so most people must love it. If you really must try it, gather your patience and do a lot of pre-game research.

2014
												Well, this was expected wasn't it!To preface this, I am playing this with Keyboard and Mouse, and it is not advised to read this if you're not okay with minor spoilers (they're tagged as spoilers, so just don't hover of them), as they're hard to avoid. Dark Souls 2 is one of the games I've enjoyed the most, I am about to wrap my first playthrough up as I enter the end game, spending nearly 50 hours on it already.In comparison to Dark Souls 1, this game does a lot of things right, and a few things wrong. This review consists of four headers, the things that went wrong, the things that went good, the things that I do not have a strong opinion of and the conclusion.Things gone wrongKeyboard and Mouse default configurationWhoever designed the default settings for keyboard and mouse wasn't doing it right - they're just nonsensical and dumb. I had to readjust a lot of keys, and the keybinding system is mediocre, but I managed to find settings to my pleasing. And once set right, the experience was smooth.TrapsThere are a few ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ized traps that you just can't see coming, like boulders, monsters suddenly breaking walls, and breaking floors that lead to oblivion.Although these things are part of the game, I feel like, especially when dying to them, these things should have been introduced differently, in perhaps a more forgiving away. As it's not a thrill introduced to you, it's just plain bull.Introduction Cinematic, and entirety of the plotThe plot feels edgy to me, you're intructed to do something, but are never told why -- except for "That you really don't know why you're doing this". The concept is silly, and you're really only doing this for a silly item. I'm sure there's more to it, but the essense of the plot really rolls around to finding a certain item, so you can use it to open doors.I really liked the plot in Dark Souls 1, Dark Souls 2 did not give this feeling to me.NPCsThe NPCs in Majula just don't give me the feeling that they're really alive. They remain in the same position and don't do much else. Their dialogue is mostly the same and they don't change a lot.Leading me onto one of the most annoying NPCs. -> The Green Maiden  I can practically dream her dialogue, she is one of the more important aspects of the game, and you constantly talk to her (i.e. to reinforce your Estus Flask, or to level up), and she always has the same dialogue.What also slightly bugs me is that the mouths never move as they talk, but that's a minor detail.PVP is unfair in certain areasIn some areas, you're forced into an area to fight another player, this other player belongs to a certain covenant. They have the clear advantage in these areas, like extra enemies, or a watery environment slowing down movement.(too much) Focus on difficulty of the wrong kindBoth a flaw and something slightly enjoyable, but I feel that the way they introduced bossfights with multiple bosses at a time is wrong, it can be right, but there are a lot of bosses that come in quantity, and lack quality. There are less unique movesets, and some are just copies of previous bosses. I don't mind multiple bosses in a bossfight, but I had hoped to keep it at minimum. To quote someone who made a review video: "You are fighting your lock on more than you are fighting the boss" Things gone rightThe PC portI'm really pleased with the PC port, it's not super-amazing, but it's well done. I've experienced no frame drops and the graphics look okay. They're not amazing, but this is a souls game. Graphics is not what it revolves around.The ExperienceIt really dragged me in, although there are many minor flaws, everything else just is good. It's not perfect, it's good. I had fun, I felt serveral emotions through (mostly agony, fear and happiness), and met some fantastic players with Jolly Cooperation. Not many games know how to ace a game where you can't communicate with eachother, but Dark Souls does it fine.Communication, Co-opAs said before, the Co-op system is great. It is like Dark Souls 1, only now it works, and it works amazingly. And it's fun.Worth for your moneyMany games are completed within serveral hours and don't have much replayability. I'm currently 50 hours in, haven't even completed it yet and am already planning ahead for my next few play throughs.Things I do not feel strongly against or forMusicI am pretty unsure of this aspect, it felt okay, but not good, nor bad. I definitely think a better job could be done on this department. But I do not remember any negative aspects of it. Therefore I do not have a strong opinion of this.ConclusionDark Souls 2 is a great game with flaws, but as does any game. I hope they fix it over time, but as it is right now the game is rather solid.The game may not be for everyone, but that's okay. If you're interested, do some research, find out if you like it. Perhaps decide to wait for it to go on sale, but I would definitely recommend this game, especially to people who liked Dark Souls 1, or people who do not get infuriated with games quickly and are okay with a learning curve that may be steep.I personally rate the game at 8.5 points out of 10. Although the bad may look greater in number; it's easier to note the things that are bad, and most of those cases are very minor in comparison to how big the Dark Souls II world really is.

												SPOILERS AHEAD: One of, if not, the best game I have ever played. It is detailed and brilliant in so many ways. It provides nerve racking experiences aslong with a side of endless frustration, and rage inducing anger. But without that, it wouldn't be a Souls game. The strongest points of the game are its story, which is never really fully explained in the game itself, and how unique the game is and the experiences it gives you. From seeing the character you have worked along side for hours and hours, finally take his place on the Throne of Want. And seeing the once been towering ex-king of Drangleic walking slowly in repeated patterns in the god forsaken Undead Crpyt. From the struggle to beat the last giant, to finding that set of armour you want, to taking your place on the throne. This is a game that you build your own story with, and have a hell of a lot of fun doing it. I am in love with every nook and cranny of this game. 10/10 extremely recommend it.

												Punishing,  Unforgiving yet so Addictive !Oh, Dark Souls 2 where do I begin. Having spend more than 1000 hours from earlier titles by FromSoftware such as the Tenchu series, Demon souls, Dark souls and now Dark souls 2. I am happy to annouce that Dark souls 2 definitely lives up to the hype shown in last year's E3 as well as all the trailers lurking around the internet and our anticipation buidling up for the april pc release.One of the biggest difference between the console version and the Pc version is that this time around, FromSoft constructed the PC version from ground up instead of porting it over which means that the graphics can be adjusted depending on the computer spec and that the experience is further enhanced by 60fps running constantly on most pcs. Textures is also much more detailed than dark souls 1 thanks for the improved game engine. Furthermore, the features provided by convenants and items all work well and match making seem to work constantly without the need to idle in the same location just to wait for an opponent.The unique match making mechanic found in dark souls 2 is also different to the first game and instead of using soul levels as a measure of player strength, the game uses soul memory (SM) so that this way it can be more balanced in both pve and pvp.The StoryOnce again, player takes on the role of a nameless hero who became the bearer of curse and arrived in the plagued and dying land of Drangleic. Only by acquiring powerful souls of the ancient, the player will be able to confront the King and the Queen which will inturn free the hero from said curse. On the surface, dark souls 2 does not provide you with 'up your face' insight in what is going on around you as well as the lore and the background. However, smart players will soon find that all the information you seek will be found by talking to npcs scattered around the world as well as reading the description of every items found in the game. This provide enough solid fact to construct an excellent rpg and enough myths left for players to interpret. GameplayFirst of all, I recommend players to have a game pad in order to play this game because keyboard and mouse control is awkward and often involve pressing keys located faraway from each other or unusual for video games. In terms of control I would say that the core mechanics is still solid and similar to the first game with minor improvements made but that is actually a good thing for veteran players and new players alike because it is intuitive in ways of switching weapons/shields and tools or spells. You only need to press the matched direction button on D-pad to allow switch of equipments. Dark souls 2 also introduced a equipment durability bar even thought it also existed in the first game. In dark souls 2 banging equipments against the wall will repel you and at the same time it will damage your equipment getting it low will be risky and lower its efficiency, breaking it will rendering it useless and require souls to be repaired by a black smith. Similarly, using heavy attack has also proven to degrade equipment at a fast pace.GraphicsBefore you go on and say anything, I know that buying a souls game for its graphics is not what the developer wanted us to do and im not saying dark souls 2 graphics is bad. In fact, it is great. Dark souls 2 features some of the most amazing visuals I have seen in recent years. From the mountain peak of Dragon Aerie to the land scape of Drangleic Castle and to the decaying undead crypt, it shows historical traits of traditional medieval fantasy perfectly and authentically portrayed in a video game. In addition to the graphic, the music is also really well composed from the intense and dangerous boss fight sound track to the grand, majestical and beautifully orchestrated music of a royal palace, the game really mixed and blended two features really well which will often get you pump and feel the sense of achievement after defeating the seemingly unbeatable bosses. Moreover, Dark souls 2 also features original voices given to the npcs of the game from the honorable knight of Mirrah to the traveller of Jugo as well as the lowly merchant of Volgen the game is really trying to create one hell of a unique and immersive experience for the player at every turn.DifficultyFromSoftware is notorious for creating difficult games that torment players and punishing them for little mistakes at the most important moment. There has also been rumours that Dark souls 2 is easier than Dark souls 1 and many features were dumbed down to make it more accessible to new players. In some way it is. However, what dark souls 2 provide with players is more freedom in what they want to do. For example if someone finds the game too easy or not challenging enough, they can use an item called 'Bonfire Ascetic' to increase the damage and the health of the enemies at the same time it reduces the amount of damage dealt by the player and if that is not enough, you can burn Bonfire Ascetics 8 times to cap the difficulty. If you wanna be even more hardcore you can also join the convenant of champions which will add another layer of difficulty and disable the co-op function to make the game solo only.VerdictOverall, I think that darksouls 2 is the best game of 2014 with amazing production value, replayability and accessbility. However, it could also be one of those game that only caters to a certain crowd of gamers.Finally, If you enjoyed the first game, you will enjoy this game even more and if you enjoy S&M you will love this game10/10

												This game is by far one of the BEST Rpg games I've played. Prepare to Die, Prepare to know your skill, Prepare to Improve. I cannot stress enough on how fun this game is. The mechanics of the game are made to counter the Hack-and-Slash point of view. (That means slashing like crazy with no bad side-effects) Where as this game if you don't plan your attacks right, if you don't try to out-think your opponents you will die, or be punished harshly. When I started playing this it made me realize that there is a MAJOR SKILL-CAP to this game. Of course there are multi-player functions, but you'll be soloing more often on mobs.AndThe PvP in the game is FORCED! This means that you'll have some really good npc's that are very player-like that will hand you your head on a platter if you don't think through what you're doing, and players will INVADE your game. This makes the game much more fun and adding a sense of "OMG I DID IT!" When you get your first player kill. Although there are some really bad sides to the game. Such as the Bell Tower. If you go in there prepared to be invaded by 3 people. So it's best to get a squad of your own before you enter the area to fight the gargoyle (optional boss). Worried about hackers? - Most of the main areas before bosses have been developed to knock off hackers with infinite hp, but they're a very small portion of the community and it isn't likely that you'll encounter one. Over all the time I've played I fought 1 hacker in the undead crypt. He ran at me with infinite hp and I shot him off the cliff using a giant arrow.This is a 100% purchase for people who want to be tested on their ability. When you start a quick suggestion is to think "Hey what type of class do I want my person to be?" Look up some guides for things like that. I also suggest a PARRY GUIDE. Especially for those people who love dual wield. Becoming good at parrying helps a lot (not for bosses though). Notes: Take your time. And there is one difficulty : DIFFICULT  But you'll get use to it quite fast.and in the words of Illidan, if you are not ready to experience a skill-check as well as having a fullfilling satisfaction then... "YOU ARE NOT PREPARED!"  And prepare to die... and have fun!

												as of 4/26/2014 due to a VAC Ban on my Profile - I have to go over to my Alt account and family share in order to Access the game online - The downside is that I am going to be unable to play that main character on this account - Although I made two characters on this account in the exctremely boring "OFFLINE" mode - Dark Souls II and the use of Multiplayer is 10000 times more important and implemented for pure strength; unlike Dark Souls 1; which from launch (Me and my buddy TRIED invading eachother; we TRIED getting in touch with eachother in game; but .... Games for windows Live sucked and we couldn't connect to eachother no matter what we tried - Thus I never completed DS1; I loved it - but in comparison to DS2 - I'd go as far as to say that DS1 was highly over-rated... Dark Souls II is the real deal.- As a PC owner you have a few different options for even prettier graphics than it launches with as well (it launches quite nice looking; and far better looking than the console versions - (Thank god Form Software figured a lot of things out and did them RIGHT this time) - With Nvidia Inspector you can use the Diablo 3 Ambient Occlusion profile; you can set up REALLY great looking AA and add FXAA with it; and you can set up HBAO+ (Gotta Love being an Nvidia User :D) - Then software allows you to DOWNSCALE RESOLUTIONS! So I set mine to 7680x4320 (Resolution; thus upping the resolution of all the textures --of everything-- to 7680x4320 then downsampling down to my Monitor's display resolution of 1920x1080 which = GORGEOUS BEYOND BELIEF - Doing this while ALSO adding the Ambient Occlusion, AA and HBAO+ is stunning (and trust me; you really dont even need Anti-Aliasing when you are Upping the Resolution on all the textures 4-5x times what "Highest" would be; - This is brilliant; and with my SLI 780 ti's I've never dipped any FPS due to having it at 7680x4320 - It runs 100% smooth and never dips out in large fights or multiplayer interaction - I believe this is the highest I will go for now; I will see it if actually supports higher texture resolution downsampling than that... if it does - then hell.. Why not!!??The game itself is just plain addiction; it is the Heroin of game launches (thus far this year atlesst :P ) - It may not be as "Hard" as some people make it out to be; but I got my self stuck in a situation where I kept dying over and over (and lost 2.5K souls; which at the time was two level ups >.< where the Tough (but pretty darn easy) mosnter was right next to the Camp; so I'd just farm him and goto the fire - reset; then to my surprise he was //No Longer Farmable// - (This was unlike DS1) - So I pushed on and got whooped at the second enemy after him due to a wrongly timed dodge; and an embarressing jumping strike that did make contact but also sent me flying 1,000 feet to my death; I can imagine all the players around that area at the time clicking on my bloodstain and seeing that; just laughing outloud - Speaking of which; The descriptive abilities for "Helpful Tips" from other players are actually "helpful" now; as you can type whatever in a longer amount of characters - You'll also find some trolls with (Honestly, amusing!) notes near the edge of cliffs "Jump down and hug the left side for treasure chest" I see about 10 bloodstains and watch these people just fall to their deaths.... Obviously no treasure - and I get quite a laugh out of it; "Tools" -rapid screenshotting-Co-op with your buddies changes DS2 for the Better 1000%; and invading other worlds with them and ganking is more fun in DS2 than in any RPG I can think of - Also with the "Jedi Knight Multiplayer" style "Honor system" people will bow prior to engaging in an actual duel; and allow themselves and the enemy to buff up (this is mostly end game from what people told me as I partook in these rituals; although doing it at an earlier level starts the great "PVP Community" mindset; With that said; I'll still gank someone who is not in it for the duel; but in it for why I'll gank them - just to appear and grab the kill while I am in the middle of a fight; thus why I chose to go with the starting item that has any mob near me aggro the outside; What can I say? Dark Souls II was MORE than WORTH THE WAIT for the PC Version - I do own a PS3; and for titles such as The Last of Us etc I will grab those excellent AAA titles that won't see daylight on PC - With Dark Souls II just as in any other title that has a release date on PC MONTHS after the console release date; I'll just wait it out - I have a friend who did not; and now aside from myself; other people he reguarly gamed with all have it on PC; and he is thinking about getting it on PC - I just sort of think the initial waiting was worth it; as we had plenty of new games to fill the time on PC prior to the DSII launch (Diablo 3 RoS for example if its the RPG funny bone that needs to be tickled) - More than worth the wait - and as nearly every reveiw states..."This is the ULTIMATE DARK SOULS 2 EXPERIENCE" or "This is now the only Dark Souls II version that gamers should buy" "The Definitive Version of Dark Souls II" - "Makes The Dark Souls II I loved on my PS3 feel 10 years older" - etc :D10/10 A+ - Wind0wned.What do I use to play? - I initially was using Keyboard and Mouse (after downloading the Input Lag Mouse Fix so I was able to actually time things correctly -laughs-) my buddy wanted me to try the Dual Shock 4 PS4 controller that I had Purchased for games that..... Only can be enjoyed with a Controller (NBA2K14 for example, Street Fighter X Tekken etc on steam) - So I ended up trying it out for him; and now I pretty much am using the DS4 70% of the time; - but either with K/Bmouse or (I prefer the Dualshock 4 to any other controller; aside from the Nvidia Shield which is the aboslute GROOVIEST experience with this game) The wind is storming in. A+ A+ A+ A+ A+

												1. The game is designed for Consol gamers, anything related to Keyboard and mouse needs to be revised to work appropriately. They took no time to convert the controls over, very sloppy and lazy.2. While the game can be fun at times, expect to die a lot early on, which is no big deal, but once you figure out how to avoid everything, it becomes stupid easy and boring. The honeymoon phase is short lived.3. Bosses are only "hard" for the sake of it, given you know how to get around it, you will feel more annoyed than happy when you defeat a boss in a fight, or relieved it's over, not like you achieved something great.4. The story is non existent.5. The locations are strung together, and it isn't really open world like I prefer, so if you like an open world like skyrim, just pass on this.6. Every area you go to, is more or less like a maze and mindless wondering, only to be engaged in PVP randomly or rekill the same things you killed 4 mins ago prior to your death. In that light, it turns into grinding, and if we're just going to kill things randomly, why not just play an MMO?7. The Games graphics are a controversial topic, for PC it is great, for consoles, I wouldn't really say they are either , it's just meh.8. The combat itself is really clunky in my opinion, but that isn't inclusive of the other variables like having a delayed response due to the lack of input or foresight of keyboard and mouse use, so aside from this point, I will say the combate is annoying. Locking on to a target should not be necessary, while swinging a weapon should not be mindless slashing praying you hit a target. For PC the combat is horrible. Unless you are a spellcaster and you just spam spells and get all the XP anyways, it becomes relatively over powered and not really fun which destroys the entire purpose of the game itself and what it is founded upon from the prior dark souls. I won't say don't get the game, aside from all that, its a good time waster if you're bored and need something new, and you may even actually come to love the game, but with the points listed above, I can not say anyone who likes Skyrim or other games, will like this game for points mentioned above. I would give the game a 7/10, But it is more average in content than anything else. If it comes down to it, buy it when it is on sale, save your money for something worth while.

												Dark Souls II is a sequel to the cult classic Dark Souls game and it unfortunately lacks every subtlety that made the first game such an intoxicating experience. To explain these subtleties would be to ruin what makes the discovery process so fun, but I will respond to anyone who wishes to know what I think in a personal Steam message.As a story telling experience, it lacks the reason to be it's own story (The DLC sort of corrects this problem.) As a combat experience, it lacks the tight mechanics that made the first one fair and engaging. The hitboxes are not as the appear at all, there is input lag on movement, and a well-designed mechanic -- rolling -- is hidden behind a stat called "Adaptation." Its level design is good, but lacks the metroid-vania style *world* design that makes it replayable. The game feels nearly as linear as a game like Darksiders does. Forgettable bosses that are just 2/3rds big armoured people with formulaic attack patterns. Dark Souls II is a pretty good Souls-*like* but pales in comparison to its predecessor. I couldn't, with good concsious, reccomend anyone looking to understand what souls is *about* by reccomending this game. As a personal aside to establish what my opinion might, or might not, mean to a review reader, I purchased the original Dark Souls four times. Once on console, twice more for friends looking to get into the game, and once on PC. I pre-purchased the deluxe edition of Dark Souls II on console and afterwards the PC version. With collectively 700+ hours into the souls series (1, 2, 3 and Bloodbourne) I still don't reccomend Dark Souls II. I would reccomend Dark Souls II *last* if you want to know what Souls is about. May the flames guide you.

												Dark Souls 2 is a decent game, but it is inferior to Dark Souls.Dark Souls 2 has managed to become a reptitive game to play, in comparison to Dark Souls. In Dark Souls 2, areas are smaller and more densely packed with enemies. In some cases, there are far too many enemies to take on without backpedaling and turtling, making getting through an area a slow process. There's many more respawn points put throughout the game, so you won't have to backtrack far if you die, but the sheer volume and tankiness of enemies makes short distances seem much longer. There's also less alternate routes to take while progressing through the game; many more of the areas are unskippable, which exacerbates the problem of enemy-saturated areas. Unlike Dark Souls, starting a new game with a character that has finished the game (called new game+, or NG+) will spawn new enemies and surprises for you to deal with. This is a nice addition, and it keeps the game fresh for a bit longer. However, many of the new enemies the game will throw at you are just very tanky and further repeats of those areas just take longer than they did before.Multiplayer in Dark Souls 2 is a straight downgrade from Dark Soul's multiplayer. In the Dark Souls series, you level up using the game's currency, "souls". You get souls from killing creatures in the game world, and it is inevitable you will get souls by progressing through the game. Previously, the level of your character determined what other players you could be matched with in Dark Souls. You could go through the game at a low level and still be able to connect to players near the beginning of the game; this allowed for overpowered co-op partners who could take out bosses very quickly, or overpowered enemy PvPers who could one-shot you. Late game, players stopped leveling at a community-decided level cap that allowed players to continue connecting to one another. The level cap encouraged players to optimize their character builds within these constraints for maximum specialization toward whatever role they wanted.Because of the imbalanced early-game PvP in Dark Souls, Dark Souls 2 has adopted a new system for matchmaking. Players are now matched according to the total number of souls they have collected, not their character level. This has a few effects, some desired, some not. Early game, players do not know how to initiate PvP, or they have little motivation to because their character builds are not complete; this makes early game PvP a rarity. As the player progresses through the game, they will have more PvP opportunities and encounters, and PvP is relatively balanced because players haven't progressed much further than each other. Late game, the total number of souls a player as collected is no longer representative of their character's ability; a character may have stopped leveling up at some point, or a character may have never stopped leveling up, and some characters may have lost a great amount of collected souls by dying. The only available option for players who wish to stay competitive in PvP is to continue leveling their character, which takes away any need to optimize or specialize one's character build. Though this new matchmaking formula fixes unfair early game PvP, it ruins the fairness and depth of late game PvP.Due to the repetitive PvE and unfair late game PvP, the game's longevity is hurt badly. There are a few other glaring issues with Dark Souls 2 that I won't go into, but despite it all, it's still a game that is above average in quality. I can't fully recommend Dark Souls 2. As a fan of Dark Souls, I've been able to keep myself interested in Dark Souls 2 for a while, but a person with more discerning taste would not tolerate Dark Souls 2 for long.Play Dark Souls before you touch this game; Dark Souls is much better game.

content:
0, 2014
												This game is truly wonderful, there's a lot of hard practice within the game and you can't just always rely on one tactic to win. Every enemy has been balanced along with the weapons and armour to always give that feeling of struggle, no matter how high in strength you are. PVP however is where this game is let down, mainly because the players who play this game like to make use of the cheapest tactics they can manage in order to win. Here's just a list of what to expect if you try doing Dark Souls 2 PVP:Channeler's trident with any magic buff and poison infusion while spamming heavy attack to drill hit you and just stack poison? Check.Infinite HP hacks? Check. (I've encountered at least 46 different players doing this so far)Poison/Bleed estoc to bypass shields? Check.Infinite stagger caestus build? Check.Prebuffing and then using poison fog/toxic mist/dark fog/acid surge as you are summoning in so you get poisoned/have your armour and rings broken before you can even act? Check. (watch out would be dragons, this happens to you a LOT)Prebuffing and then trying to backstab you as you are summoning in? Check (Dragons again...)Waiting right by where you appear and spamming fire tempest or other AoE spells so you have no time to act when you summon in? Check. (dragons especially)Abusing rolls to ensure no form of magic will ever hit them? Check. (Oh yeah, if you roll? You can't get hit by most magic unless it's a flat out hit. Not a fun thing if you get forced into PVP and you're a caster of any form).That's just a short list of the cheap tactics I've seen being put to use while I have played Dark Souls 2. Players will not try to play fair and as a result, it ruins the experience for the people who are trying to play the game fairly. Most even take PRIDE in this factor and you can find tons of builds to accompany these tactics so as to 'pwn maximum number of noobs' as one person put it.I will complement Dark Souls 2 however as it has made co-operative play (especially with friends) much, MUCH better than Dark Souls 1. You get a name engraved ring you can buy that allows you to connect to players using the same 'god' that you choose using the ring. There's a large selection of gods and goddesses so you have little risk of being summoned by someone who you don't want to be summoned by. There's also two forms of aid you can do: Shades (which last a certain time and vanish when they've either killed so many enemies or have been there long enough, you can tell if a shade's about to vanish because they start turning black) and phantoms (Just like Dark Souls 1, they vanish when you beat a boss usually). A nice thing they've made sure to note is while there are areas where phantoms can't be summoned, shades can still be summoned in some of them, allowing for you to still recieve aid from your friends if you need it (and some areas you really DO need it.For those travelling alone, From Software hasn't forgotten about you. Almost every single boss has a NPC phantom or two somewhere nearby that can aid you if you are unfortunate enough to have the dark souls 2 server lose connection or if you lose connection to steam. What's more, some of them have storylines that grant you their equipment if you accomplish them.Overall, there's plenty of nice things in Dark Souls 2 that I would really want to praise. There's a vast array of weapons, armours and items to help you on your journey and it's possible to make all kinds of playthroughs (I've even seen someone playing a run as a character named after and tooled up exactly like Simon Belmont from castlevania. That was funny to play along with!).If anything, it's Dark Souls 2's PVP that lets it down in the long run and a lot of the covenants make use of PVP to rank up so you are kind of forced to face it at some point if you want the most out of covenants... though thankfully you can switch covenants freely in Dark Souls 2, which is a god send.There was one other thing that disappointed me though (and this is more a personal nitpick than anything else)... the weapons while vast and arrayed... well, it doesn't exactly have the same kind of fantastic variety that Dark Souls 1 had. I thought it was neat when I could get a sword made out of crystal or the dark sword from the darkwraiths (I was pleased the armour was back but COME ON FROM SOFT, why no sword to go with!?) which all had really unique designs and stood out. Granted, there are a few nice and unique weapons but I just feel it's lacking there. Who knows? Maybe the DLC coming out will provide us with some more really neat tools of destruction? I sure hope so!Would I recommend Dark Souls 2? Yes, VERY MUCH YES I would recommend this game. But there are things that you need to be aware of when you pick this game up and I hope this review will help those who are considering this game for various reasons to consider before picking it up. From Software is making constant balance checks with this game so maybe they might see some of the problems and deal with them but in the meantime, thank you for reading my review and I hope it gave you all information about Dark Souls 2 that will help you decide to buy the game.Good luck, and hope you're prepared to die all over again. You'll be doing it a lot.

												A sequel , that PC player deserved. I have heard about the start trouble for some problem and I know it is not a good thing , but do not judge the game for having these problem, but the Developers. I did not have any problem with the PC version after the release.The PC version is far better than the console version. 60 FPS, better textures and a great Network connection.You can run this game with a mid-PC on High/Very High with stable 60 fps, which surprised me.There are problems with the Keyboard and Mouse controls, but when you get used to it, it is not that bad.But yeah, they should have worked on KB+M more. The atmosphere and the music fits perfectly in that game and there are many places to explore. Some locations even remind you of the prequel.Dark Souls 2 is a mix of Demon's and Dark Souls, which makes the gameplay so good.The beginning of the game is very good for beginners of the Souls series, but when you are a Veteran , you can skip the tutorial. Most of the Boss fights are good, but I do not recall a "great" fight. So you almost forget about most boss fights, sadly. The game is still challanging , which is good, but sometimes the challange gets too hard, which can frustrate you.The lore itself is as mysterious as DeS and DaS and it keeps you wondering , what happened in the past.I really enjoyed Dark Souls 2 and I hope From Software will take care of this game in the future.I can really recommend it to everyone, who likes to have a challange in games or who are still unsure, if they want to buy the PC or Console version and of course for Soul-Series fans.
